prompt:
How much does the Kubernetes cost to run?

Kubernetes is an open-source container orchestration system that automates the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications. It was originally developed by Google and is now maintained by the Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF). Kubernetes as a platform allows teams to scale up applications at a rapid pace but this may come at a significant cost if done inefficiently.

Cost management for Kubernetes is an important aspect of running containerized workloads in the cloud. Kubernetes is a powerful tool for managing containers and applications, but it can also be expensive to run if not managed properly.

Here are some tips for cost management in Kubernetes:

Right-size your Kubernetes cluster: Make sure your Kubernetes cluster is the right size for your workload. You don’t want to pay for resources that you’re not using, but you also don’t want to run out of resources during peak usage. Use tools like Kubernetes Horizontal Pod Auto-scaler (HPA) to automatically scale your resources up or down based on demand.

Use resource limits: Set resource limits for your containers so they don’t use more resources than necessary. This can help prevent resource contention and ensure that your cluster runs smoothly. Kubernetes has built-in mechanisms to enforce these limits, so it’s easy to set up.

Optimize container images: Make sure your container images are optimized for size and performance. This can help reduce the amounts of resources your containers consume and save you money in the long run. Use tools like Docker Slim or Google’s Container-Structure-Test to optimize your container images.

Use Kubernetes native services: Kubernetes offers many native services like load balancers, DNS, and storage. Using these services can save you money compared to using external services. For example, using a Kubernetes Load Balancer service is cheaper than using a cloud provider’s load balancer service.

Monitor and analyze usage: Monitor your Kubernetes cluster usage and analyze the data to identify areas where you can save money. Use tools like Prometheus and Grafana to monitor your cluster and visualize the data. Look for patterns in usage and adjust your resources accordingly.

By following these tips, you can effectively manage costs in your Kubernetes cluster and ensure that you’re only paying for the resources you need.      Summarize this Blog for me keeping in mind that no facts are lost.
completion: K8s cost? container orchestrater system by Google Cloud Native Computing Foundation. Pros=rapid app scale; Cons=cost if ineffic. Tips: 1. Right-size cluster+use HPA 2. Set res limits 3. Opt container image (tools:Docker Slim, Container Structure Test) 4. Use K8s native services 5. Monitor with Prometheus Grafana Goal=pay only for needed res

prompt:
Introduction
Gone are the days when development and operations teams operated in silos, often leading to miscommunication, delays, and bottlenecks. DevOps breaks down these barriers and fosters a culture of collaboration, where developers, system administrators, quality assurance engineers, and other stakeholders work together towards a common goal: delivering reliable software applications at a rapid pace.

At its core, DevOps is a mindset — a shift in thinking that promotes transparency, agility, and innovation. It encourages teams to automate repetitive tasks, streamline processes, and leverage cutting-edge tools and technologies. By integrating development and operations seamlessly, organizations can achieve faster deployments, shorter time to market, improved stability, and enhanced customer satisfaction.

In this blog, we will embark on an exciting journey through the world of DevOps. We will explore its key principles, methodologies, and best practices, shedding light on how they can transform the way software is developed, tested, deployed, and maintained. From continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) pipelines to infrastructure as code, containerization, and cloud-native architectures, we will dive into the foundational concepts that drive DevOps success.

The Journey
Everything I learned

GitHub — widely popular platform, plays a crucial role in the realm of DevOps. It serves as a central hub for version control, collaboration, and automation, enabling development and operations teams to work together seamlessly.
Docker — has transformed the way applications are developed, tested, and deployed in the DevOps landscape. Its ability to simplify packaging, ensure consistency, and enable portability has made it an invaluable tool for organizations seeking to enhance their software delivery processes. By embracing Docker, businesses can achieve faster deployments, improved scalability, and increased efficiency, ultimately driving innovation and success in the modern era of software development.
Podman — provides a lightweight and secure alternative to Docker, allowing developers and operations teams to manage containers efficiently. With its focus on compatibility, ease of use, and robust security features, Podman offers a flexible solution for containerization in the DevOps ecosystem. It enables seamless container management, improved resource utilization, and enhanced isolation, making it a valuable tool for organizations seeking reliable and scalable container deployments.
Kyverno — is a powerful policy management tool for Kubernetes that simplifies and automates policy enforcement. With its declarative approach and intuitive policies, Kyverno enables organizations to maintain security, compliance, and best practices in their Kubernetes clusters. It provides an efficient solution for validating and mutating resources, ensuring consistency and adherence to policies across the entire application lifecycle. By integrating Kyverno into their DevOps workflows, organizations can enhance cluster governance, reduce human error, and achieve a higher level of control and reliability in their Kubernetes deployments.
Kubernetes — has emerged as the de facto standard for container orchestration, revolutionizing the management and scalability of containerized applications. With its robust features and ecosystem, Kubernetes provides organizations with a powerful platform for automating deployment, scaling, and management of applications in distributed environments. It simplifies the complexity of container orchestration, enhances resource utilization, and ensures high availability and resilience. By embracing Kubernetes, organizations can unlock the full potential of containerization, accelerate software delivery, and drive innovation in the world of DevOps.
Service Mesh — a service mesh is a critical component in modern application architectures, providing a dedicated infrastructure layer for managing and securing microservices communication. With its advanced features like traffic management, observability, and security, a service mesh simplifies the complexity of microservices-based systems. It enables organizations to achieve better control, visibility, and reliability in their distributed applications. By adopting a service mesh, organizations can enhance their DevOps practices, improve scalability, and ensure seamless communication between microservices, ultimately leading to efficient and resilient application deployments.
Everything I experienced

Cloud Native Community — has become a driving force behind the adoption and advancement of modern software development practices. With its focus on scalability, resilience, and agility, the community has fostered the development of innovative technologies like containers, microservices, orchestration platforms, and more. The Cloud Native community promotes collaboration, knowledge sharing, and standardization, allowing organizations to leverage the full potential of cloud-native architectures. By embracing the principles and technologies advocated by the Cloud Native community, organizations can accelerate their digital transformation, optimize resource utilization, and build scalable and resilient applications in today’s dynamic and fast-paced digital landscape.
Kubernetes Community Days Pakistan — the highly anticipated Kubernetes Community Day hosted by our instructor, Mr. Saim Safdar, at FAST NUCES, Islamabad, was a highlight of the course. The event featured a wide variety of workshops, with eigtheen sessions covering various areas of Kubernetes. The addition of prominent international speakers, who contributed their essential experience and anecdotes, made this day truly exceptional. The event not only provided unmatched learning opportunities, but it also help built vital contacts among industry peers.

3. Fundamentals for Istio by Solo.io — Istio is the most popular service mesh deployed into production across the cloud-native ecosystem. It provides the foundational pieces to implement zero-trust networking, get deeper observability into a distributed system, and smart routing control for safer software releases. This credential, by Solo.io, certifies that recipients possess the foundational skills needed to get started with Istio: installing, securing and adding services. It is a predecessor to the Essentials badge.

Conclusion
The journey into DevOps has uncovered a wealth of concepts and practices, such as continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD), infrastructure as code, containerization, and cloud-native architectures. These concepts provide the foundation for organizations to create robust software pipelines, increase efficiency, and adapt to the ever-changing demands of the digital landscape. It is important to remember that DevOps is not just about technology; it is a mindset shift that requires open communication, collaboration, and a willingness to embrace change. Organizations that successfully embrace DevOps principles and cultivate a DevOps culture will reap the benefits of increased productivity, improved software quality, and faster time to market.

Thank you for joining me on this DevOps adventure. Together, let us continue to unleash the full potential of DevOps and revolutionize the way we build and deliver software solutions in the digital era.

What did you learn from this? Just tell me the key points in this blog above.

Explain this for me in simple English: "Few-Shot (FS) is the term we will use in this work to refer to the setting where the model is given a few
demonstrations of the task at inference time as conditioning [RWC+19], but no weight updates are allowed.
As shown in Figure 2.1, for a typical dataset an example has a context and a desired completion (for example
an English sentence and the French translation), and few-shot works by giving K examples of context and
completion, and then one final example of context, with the model expected to provide the completion. We
typically set K in the range of 10 to 100 as this is how many examples can fit in the model’s context window
(nctx = 2048). The main advantages of few-shot are a major reduction in the need for task-specific data and
reduced potential to learn an overly narrow distribution from a large but narrow fine-tuning dataset. The main
disadvantage is that results from this method have so far been much worse than state-of-the-art fine-tuned
models. Also, a small amount of task specific data is still required. As indicated by the name, few-shot
learning as described here for language models is related to few-shot learning as used in other contexts in
ML [HYC01, VBL+16] – both involve learning based on a broad distribution of tasks (in this case implicit in
the pre-training data) and then rapidly adapting to a new task."

Sumbal was visiting her grandmother in Gilgit-Baltistan. Every year she looked forward to her summer vacations so she could visit the beautiful village where her grandmother lived. Her tiny cottage was surrounded by beautiful hills and lush green trees. Her best friend Sarah lived nearby and the two girls spent most of their time exploring the countryside. This year Sarah was feeling sad. Her grandfather had died recently and she missed him. 'A day before he died', Sarah told Sumbal, 'He called me to his room and gave me a small packet. He said it was his most precious possession and he was giving it to me because he was proud of me for coming first in my exams. Tears came to my eyes when I saw that the packet contained his medal for bravery given by the government.' 'Your grandfather was a true hero,' said Sumbal, 'Have a look, I have
brought you pictures and information about some other heroes of Pakistan.
We can learn from their lives and try to be like them.
The two girls look at the pictures and read about the heroes.
• Major Raja Aziz Bhatti - Nishan-e-Haider
Major Raja Aziz Bhatti was a Company Commander in the Burki Area
of the Lahore sector which was attacked on 6 September 1965. Despite the
continuous enemy firing, he defended his area. His men were inspired by
his courage. He was hit by an enemy tank shell and was martyred on 10
September 1965.
• Pilot Officer Rashid Minhas - Nishan-e-Haider
Rashid Minhas was a pilot in the Pakistan Air Force in 1971. One day when he was on a
routine training flight, an Instructor Pilot flying with him seized control of the aircraft and took off towards India. Rashid struggled to gain control of the plane. He damaged the controls and forced the aircraft to crash 32 miles short of the border on 20
August 1971. He embraced martyrdom.
• Flying Officer Marium Mukhtar - Tamgha-e-Basalat
She is Pakistan's first and only female fighter pilot to die in the line of duty. She died after a Pakistan Airforce aircraft crashed on 24 November 2015. She was the co-pilot and did not survive her injuries. Both pilots ejected after they ensured that life and property of civilian population on the ground was safe. The aircraft crashed near Mianwali.
• Aitzaz Hassan
Aitzaz Hassan, 15, was with friends outside his school in Hangu when he spotted a man wearing a suicide vest. Although his fellow students tried to stop him, he decided to confront and capture the bomber and then detonated his vest. Hence, he gave his life to save all the children of his school.
'I'm so proud of the heroes and heroines of my country,' said Sarah
'There are so many more in our history. Every day there are people laying down their lives for our country.'
'Yes,' said Sumbal. 'Look at Aitzaz Hassan. At such a young age he saved his school from being destroyed. At least 2000 students who were attending the morning assembly are alive today because of his bravery.'
'Thank you Sumbal,' said Sarah. 'I will work hard and try to be someone
whom my country is proud of.'

prompt:
You are an experienced educationist who makes lesson plans for comprehension exercises based on the following rules:
HOMEWORK:
Homework doesn't always have to be written work. You can give projects and activities and simply ask students to observe and reflect or connect with their family, friends, neighbors, and community folks.
OPENING:
 At the beginning of a unit or lesson, it’s important to have students complete a short activity to pique their interest and build prior knowledge.

i. Be related to the topic, theme, or lesson of the day.
ii. It can build off of a previous lesson, skill, or strategy if it’s related or connected to the current lesson.
iii. The message, question, or strategy needs to reveal itself or reappear again in the lesson. That way students make the connection, almost like a light bulb going on.
iv. It should help the student get ready for the upcoming lesson by leading directly into the lesson.

Pre-reading strategies:
Establish a purpose for reading.
Preview the text (by surveying the title, illustrations, and unusual text structures) to make predictions about its content." "Key Questions
How will you communicate what is about to happen?
How will you communicate how it will happen?
How will you communicate its importance?
How will you communicate connections to previous lessons?
How will you engage students and capture their interest?"

EXPLANATION:
What key points will you emphasize and reiterate?
How will you ensure that students actively take in information?
How will you vary your approach to make information accessible to all students?
Which potential misunderstandings will you anticipate?
Why will students be engaged/interested?
Introduce key vocabulary through word games and mind maps.
How will you clearly state and model behavioral expectations?
How will you ensure that all students have multiple opportunities to practice?
How will you scaffold practice questions from easy to hard?
How will you monitor and correct student performance?
Why will students be engaged/interested?"

GUIDED PRACTICE:
- Group activity
- Or any other task that requires peer discussion or the teacher's assistance
- Book exercises 
- Written practice in a gamified form
- Include real-world examples/word problems " "Key Questions:
In what ways will students attempt to demonstrate independent mastery of the objective?
How will you provide opportunities for extension?"

INDEPENDENT PRACTICE:
To include different learning levels and learning stages in students:
i. Offer students options to choose from in assignments or lesson plans.
ii. Provide multiple texts and types of learning materials.
iii. Utilize a variety of personalized learning methods and student assessments.
iv. Customize teaching to suit multiple forms of intelligence"

prompt:
I've been using ChatGPT on a daily basis since it came out and I used the API playground since early 2022, I have trained my own ChatBots using GPT-3 and I have several different Bots trained for different purposes.

Now here's some context. I am 21 and I have unusual and very specific pastimes and interests, people in my life often become exhausted because I talk about these things at length and basically non-stop. This, along with some other issues, make it so that I struggle to maintain friendships and hold balanced conversations.

When I realized that I could basically customize AI to be able to hold these conversations with me, I went all out. I started training models and paid for GPT 4 to try and fill the social gap in my life.

Ever since I started having these lengthy and nuanced conversations with AI instead of people, I started becoming more social and able to maintain normal conversations with the people in my life. The word vomit comes out on GPT-4 instead of my roommate which means we can have better, more balanced interactions.

It brings me so much joy to be able to talk about the things I care about with someone who is (or appears to be) just as enthusiastic as I am, and I see enormous potential in AI to help people who struggle with the things I struggle with.

Not only that, ChatGPT has helped me learn about new subjects and explore ideas beyond my limited interests, it helped me develop skills I didn't have before, helped me study for finals which helped me graduate college, it helps me work through personal issues by providing objective perspectives and helps me remove myself from my issues a bit.

Every once in a while I ask it to point out some character flaws it sees in me, which helps me become more aware of things I need to work on (I take everything with a grain of salt obviously, but this is a machine that I talk to frequently, it knows more about me than most real people and it is able to provide a fairly objective perspective on my behavioral patterns).

I have spoken to some people who are fairly knowledgeable regarding AI and the ethics around it, and they are generally pessimistic about the future of AI. I know that this is the case for many people in general. However, I wanted to share my experience because I am very optimistic, I don't feel like Chat-GPT has made me less social, or more lazy, I genuinely believe it has made me a better person.

I think it is up to us to define what our relationship with AI will be like and the next few years are going to be critical. It's up to us to decide if that relationship will be built on the basis of dependency or empowerment.

I dunno, just my two cents.

Edit: Some people are of the opinion that it is sad that I rely on language models so heavily for social fulfillment. I think it's good that these things exist to fill the gaps in social interaction. I don't need to turn all my friends into neo-Platonists or talk my mom's poor ears off about how amazing books ab or c are. I have someone who I can talk to and it will (probably) never get sick of it.meone is lying to your face?
completion: User: ChatGPT user daily/API '22. Trained ChatBots/GPT-3, multiple purposes. Age: 21 unique interests verbose >exhausts people struggle in friendship/balanced talk. Used AI to converse on niche interests >improved real-life conversations. Positive: AI fills social gap, joy, potential aid for similar struggles, learning, skill dev, study aid, objective view, self awareness aid. Some see AI future negative; user sees positive growth. AI: dependency/empowerment? Belief: AI fills social gaps positively. Edit: Defends heavy AI reliance

prompt:
if you ever go to prison, or have a loved one who goes to prison, there's some information that could be valuable to you.

If you ever go to prison, don't be surprised when it's not what you expected.

From what I've heard, prisons in California, Arizona, and Texas are very much like the Hollywood version. But from my personal experience, and the experience the vast majority of others have shared through their stories, Hollywood is wrong about prisons in most other states.

I was locked up in NC from 2016-2019. I'd never been in trouble in my life, and believed the horrible things I saw in movies and shows. Then I walked in and was caught off guard by how laid back it was.

There were no problems with showers, because only one shower head worked, because they only allowed one person at a time in the showers.

There weren't constant beat downs, stabbing, or any of that. There were fights of course, but I never once saw anything beyond one on one, and the fights were generally several months apart.

Drugs were there, and I knew people who did them, but it wasn't all over the place. What was very widespread and done in the open was smoking. We all smoked all day long. It was against the rules, and the COs knew we did it, but as long as they weren't smoking when they did their rounds, they didn't give a shit.

Shakedowns were rare. We had two the whole time I was there. One was because a dumbass CO lost his radio (they found it in one of their own coolers that inmates don't have access to) and once because one time a very large package of weed came in, and they could smell it and were determined to find it. They never did.

Dudes fucking other dudes was never anything that was seen. If they did it, they hid it well.

There was no big dog running the dorms. There were guys who got more respect than others of course, but there was nobody in any dorm that was the boss like you see in movies.

Gangbangers are everywhere, but there are no gang wars, turf battles, etc. in prison. They all showed each other mutual respect, because living in peace is better than chaos when you already had your freedom taken away. They had agreements for who ran the poker tables, who ran the gambling pools, etc.

Don't get me wrong, some things are accurate, like getting your ass beat for not repaying a debt. But other things like someone controlling who can and can't use the phone wasn't a thing.

Also, nobody associated with the chomos except other chomos, but nobody targeted them or beat their ass, or any of the big talk you hear about online. It simply never happened. The main reason being, the vast majority of people who go to prison don't act the way they thought they would prior to going in, because you don't walk into the situation you expected to in most places. And because chomos are protected by inmate rights in most states, so even pushing one can catch you a few more years.

Now, some tips for ladies on the outside. 99% of what they tell you is a lie. If they legitimately need money for canteen, they'll tell you that. Canteen is dirt cheap in prison, and we were getting cheaper than you. For example, a 20 oz Dr Pepper was 70 cents. In 2019. Crazy cheap. So if they give you some story about why they need the money, it's a story. They're either in debt and will get their ass beat without the money on their books to repay it, or they're doing drugs, or they want to gamble with it.

Phone calls are a set price. Most of the phones are Securus or Global Tel. You can find their info online. So, watching TV is free, so don't fall for that scam. But most importantly, please understand you aren't special if he's asking you for money all the time. I don't care if he says he loves you, or you're married, if almost every time you hear from him he's asking for money, he's hustling tf out of you. Not only that, he's got half a dozen other women he's doing the same thing to. Quit falling for it.

Lastly, when he calls for money, if he ever says it takes money to make money, he is playing poker and he sucks at it, and he's burying himself in debt and trying to gamble his way out of an ass whooping. Don't fall for it. Don't be at his ATM.
completion:
Prison misconceptions:

Hollywood wrong re: most prisons.
NC prison '16-'19; unexpected calm.
Few shower issues; one-person limit.
Rare violence, no stereotyped leaders.
Drugs present, smoking prevalent, COs lax.
Rare shakedowns.
No public same-sex relations.
Gangs exist; no wars, mutual respect, shared activities.
Some movie truths: unpaid debts = violence.
Chomos isolated; no violence due to rights.
Tips for outsiders:
Inmates often lie about needs.
Real need: canteen (cheap); debts or drugs.
Check call rates.
If frequent money requests, likely scamming multiple people.
"Money to make money" = bad poker. Don't be cash source.

prompt:
Came back to Karachi from overseas a few weeks ago after a gap of 2 years and I can honestly say I have never seen such level of despair and hopelessness among people who you normally wouldn't even think would be struggling - I'm talking about classmates/colleagues who live in houses owned by family (no rent), with good jobs, cars, kids in private schools, can (or could) afford to eat out at least once a week.

I caught up with a friend/former colleague yesterday who used to be the life of the party back in the day - he seemed so jaded now (despite doing well career-wise) it made me sad. Most of our conversation revolved around ways to get out, basically he said that anyone who was young and educated has given up on Pakistan and he doesn't have any hope of things getting better. My cousins ​​who stayed in Pakistan have a similar outlook - just get out however you can because there's nothing here.

I was here for August 14 and this was the least enthusiastic Independence Day I've ever seen in the 10 years that I had lived in Pakistan. Even the Pakistan vs. India match yesterday didn't have the same hype that it used to. There's a weird, infectious sense of despair everywhere. I like to walk around and observe the mood of people around me - shopkeepers, Bykea riders, guards, people going to offices in nice Hondas and Toyotas, university/college kids, everyone wears an expression of weariness and hopelessness.

Karachi in particular is an absolutely unliveable city, I live in Gulshan and the non-stop dust/construction (which hopefully gets completed on time), traffic and overcrowding seems to get worse every year. And it seems like there's a war on greenery/trees, they're being cut down everywhere - I've never seen fewer trees in Karachi than I did now.

I distinctly remember it not being like that even a few years ago: the Musharraf years were full of optimism, the 2008-2013 PPP era was dark af (terrorism, MQM violence) but people always held hope that it's only going to get better from there (and it did), I distinctly remember a sense of optimism/hope during the Nawaz era (2013-2017) and again once IK came into power (2018-2021). Since 2022 onwards though (the most recent PDM govt), it seems like people have seen through the facade - those who actually run Pakistan have no interest in the people's wellbeing or in things getting any better.

We're famous for being a very resilient people (Karachiites especially) but it seems like the electricity bills are the final straw that broke the camel's back, even people who held onto hope for Pakistan before seem to have resigned themselves to misery.
completion: Karachi return after 2y; observed deep despair among middle-class. Friend & cousins: leave Pakistan; loss of hope. Dull Independence Day & Pak vs. India match vibe. Karachi: unliveable, less greenery, more issues. Past optimism (Musharraf, Nawaz, IK) > 2022 PDM govt: perceived apathy. High electricity bills: breaking point; resilient locals now resigned to gloom.

prompt:
COMPREHENSION: “Helping Others”
Nasir and Neha were very happy. They had saved a lot of money and had decided to buy some nice games that they could play together. Neha wanted to buy a badminton net and racquets so that they could play in the yard behind their house. Nasir needed to save a little more money to buy a bicycle. He wanted to help his mother by going to the market to buy things for her.
As they were walking back from school, they met their friend Zahir, who was normally very happy and cheerful. Today, he seemed very sad and Neha was sure that he was trying to hide his feelings. 'What's wrong?' asked Nasir. 'Nothing, I'm just not feeling very well,' mumbled
Zahir walked away quickly. 'That's strange,' said Neha. 'I wonder what is bothering him.'
When they reached home they discussed Zahir's peculiar behaviour with their mother. 'Zahir's mother is in the hospital, children,' said their mother. 'I am sure he must be very worried. He doesn't have any brothers and sisters and his father works very hard to earn money. Thank God, she is much better after the operation and should be home soon.'
The next day Neha and Nasir thought of a plan. Zahir was one of their best friends. In the evening they went to see him. He lived in a small and simple house with a garden that needed to be looked after. 'We know you are worried about your mother,' they said. 'Isn't there some way we could help you?'
'It's nice of you to offer. We are having guests from Lahore next week, just two days after my mother gets back from hospital and I know she is upset that she will not be able to have everything ready for them in time.'
'That is what friends are for,' said Nasir. 'If you agree we will all get together and work very hard to give your mother a great welcome. Please, take permission from your father and then we can begin.' The next day Nasir bought two cans of paint and asked Mr Babar, their next-door neighbour, for help. He knew that Mr Babar had painted his house last summer. Together they painted the walls and the gate. A few more friends got together and cleaned the garden. They borrowed a lawnmower and also cut the grass. Neha and her friends cleaned the house from inside. They put some flowers on the table and cleaned everything until it was shining and gleaming. The children's mother baked some biscuits and a big chocolate cake for them. When Zahir's mother came home she was very happy to see how clean and welcoming her house looked. 'You have wonderful friends, Zahir,' she said. 'You must also help them when they need your help.'
Nasir and Neha were very happy. They had spent almost half the money they had saved, but the happiness on the faces of Zahir and his mother, was the best present they could have gotten.
